headline: Regional Upheaval
summary: As protesters swarmed in Tunisia and Egypt, eventually toppling the long-time rulers in both places, other Arab leaders have scrambled to diffuse unrest at home. Track the protests day-by-day.

headline: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: Corrections & Amplifications

headline: Rate Increases on Cards Have Eased
summary: The nation's new consumer watchdog agency plans to release a report Tuesday saying banks have eased up on credit-card rate increases and turned more consumer-friendly over the past year.

headline: KPMG Will Buy EquaTerra
summary: Auditing firm KPMG is expected to announce Tuesday the acquisition of EquaTerra, a privately owned outsourcing advisory firm.

headline: Remaining Mills Struggle in 'Sock Capital'
summary: Fort Payne, a rural town in Alabama, was once nicknamed the 'Official Sock Capital of the World.' Today, all but 14 of the mills are shuttered. Terry Locklear, owner of one of the remaining mills, Emi-G Knitting Inc., is modernizing his sock business amid record-high cotton prices.

headline: Handful Respond to Call for Protests
summary: Chinese authorities detained dozens of political activists after an anonymous online call for people to start a 'Jasmine Revolution' in China by protesting in 13 cities—just a day after President Hu Jintao called for tighter Internet controls to help prevent social unrest.

headline: Best Buy to Close China Stores
summary: Best Buy Co. is closing its namesake stores in China and shifting new U.S. store growth to smaller formats instead of its familiar big boxes, as the electronics giant tries to realign capital to more fruitful ventures.

headline: Trailer Living in the Hamptons Area
summary: One of the nation's largest owners of trailer parks paid nearly $22 million for the 101-acre Thurm's Estates community in Calverton, N.Y. A look inside the trailer park.

headline: Mideast Turmoil Hits European Stocks; Japan Down on Tuesday
summary: European shares fell sharply Monday, led by the financial sector, on nervousness over political unrest in the Middle East and North Africa. Italian shares dropped 3.6%. Chinese stocks gained, and Tokyo edged higher. Asia markets began Tuesday morning weaker.

headline: Bank of America Card Unit Takes $20.3 Billion Regulatory Charge
summary: Bank of America's credit-card subsidiary is restating eight quarters of reports to regulators because it took a $20.3 billion write-down due to deteriorating credit and new regulations over the past two years.

headline: P.T. Walkley: As Heard on TV
summary: Though he's performed at Madison Square Garden with Coldplay, P.T. Walkley spends his days composing music for Nickelodeon's "Team Umizoomi."

headline: White House Eyes Budget Contingencies
summary: White House officials have begun reviewing the potential impact of a brief lapse in new government funding if Congress doesn't pass a temporary spending measure by March 4.

headline: BASF Earnings May Signal Chemical Sector's Strength
summary: When BASF SE reports full-year earnings Thursday, the German chemical company's outlook should provide some insight into how much of last year's momentum will carry into 2011.

headline: Both Sides Hold Firm in Wisconsin
summary: With the Wisconsin governor maintaining a hard line on his budget bill and Democratic senators refusing to return to Madison, attention is turning to a group of moderate Republican senators to negotiate a compromise.

headline: U.S.: Halt 'Unacceptable Bloodshed'
summary: The U.S. condemned mounting violence against protesters in Libya, demanding that the regime immediately halt the "unacceptable bloodshed" taking place on its streets.

headline: Everbright Plans Hong Kong Listing
summary: China Everbright Bank said it plans to sell up to 12 billion new shares ahead of a Hong Kong listing, making it the latest Chinese lender to turn to the capital markets in the face of continuing monetary-tightening drive.

headline: U.K.'s Cameron Condemns Violence in Libya
summary: U.K. Prime Minister David Cameron condemned the violence against protesters in Libya during a visit to Cairo Monday, the first by a Western leader since a popular uprising forced President Hosni Mubarak out of office 10 days ago.

headline: CSR to Acquire Zoran
summary: CSR agreed to pay $679 million for U.S. video-chip specialist Zoran in a  deal designed to integrate the two companies' technologies.

headline: Topshop's Autumn 2011 Collection
summary: Sir Philip Green's High Street brand, known for its sixth fashion sense and designer collaborations, sent a steady stream of 1930s-inspired looks down the runway.

headline: Mullen Meets Saudi Military Officials
summary: The top U.S. uniformed military officer met with Saudi military officials Sunday to discuss the pro-democracy protests roiling the Middle East and whether Iran was seeking to take advantage of the unrest.

headline: Temasek Taps CICC Banking Chief
summary: Temasek appointed Ding Wei, the investment-banking chief at China International Capital Corp., to head its China operations.

headline: Halifax Returns to Haunt Lloyds
summary: Lloyds Banking Group said it has set aside $811.7 million to cover goodwill payments to some Halifax mortgage customers, as its acquisition of lender HBOS during the financial crisis continues to cause it financial losses.

headline: Moammar Gadhafi's Libya
summary: Col. Moammar Gadhafi has ruled for decades with an iron fist, tolerating little political opposition, but, in recent weeks, Libya has seen large-scale protests erupt, just as its North African neighbors. See some key dates in Col. Gadhafi's nearly 42-year reign.

headline: Kirin Drug Unit to Buy  ProStrakan of Scotland
summary: Japanese pharmaceutical company Kirin agreed to buy Scotland's Pro Strakan for $474 million in an effort to expand its cancer-drug business outside Japan.

headline: Egypt Freezes Mubaraks' Assets
summary: Egyptian law-enforcement officials froze the financial assets of former President Hosni Mubarak and his family amid an investigation into the deposed president's business practices, according to a person familiar with the matter at the General Prosecutor's office.

headline: Luxottica Founder Resigns From Generali Board
summary: Leonardo Del Vecchio, founder and chairman of eyewear manufacturer Luxottica, resigned from the board of Generali, the Italian insurer said.

headline: Obama Administration Wants PunishmentFor Libyan Violence
summary: The Obama administration, citing reports that hundreds of antigovernment protesters had been killed and injured in Libya, demanded that Col. Moammar Gadhafi's regime punish officials responsible for the violence.

headline: European Stocks Sink on Mideast Tension
summary: European stocks fell sharply Monday, led by the financial sector. Italian shares were hit particularly hard by the Libyan turmoil, falling 3.6%. Greek banks tumbled.

headline: Woodside Petroleum Posts Profit Rise, Progress on Pluto Expansion
summary: Woodside Petroleum reported a 6.9% rise in annual profit and said it is closer to a supply deal with a rival to underpin an expansion of its $14.2 billion) Pluto natural-gas project in Australia.

headline: Libyan Unrest Gets Oil Market's Attention
summary: Turmoil in the Middle East has spread to a major oil producer for the first time, sending Brent crude to $105 per barrel, a level not seen since September 2008. The move reflects concern the crisis may spread to other producers.

headline: Libya Unrest Appears to Grow
summary: Demonstrations against Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi appeared to grow amid reports of violent clashes between protesters and security forces in several cities, including unconfirmed reports of unrest on the outskirts of Tripoli.

headline: After Weekend of Meetings, Anthony Ready for Deal
summary: Denver Nuggets star says meetings with Knicks and Nets owners were "good" and he hopes for resolution soon.

headline: Japanese Yields Creep Higher
summary: Yields on Japanese government bonds edged higher as investors positioned themselves for Tuesday's auction of 20-year debt.

headline: India's Steel Authority Plans Overseas Expansion
summary: State-run Steel Authority of India is looking to set up steel plants in Indonesia, Mongolia, South Africa and Oman with a total investment of $12 billion.

headline: Bundesbank Opposes EU Fund Expansion
summary: Germany's central bank hit out at proposals to expand the euro-zone bailout fund, arguing that would lead to an unjustifiable burden on taxpayers in creditor countries.

headline: Strauss-Kahn Still Elusive on Plans
summary: Dominique Strauss-Kahn gave his strongest hints yet that he was unlikely to seek a second mandate as managing director of the International Monetary Fund, but stopped short of giving an answer over whether he will run in France's 2012 presidential elections.

headline: Iraqi Lawmakers Move Funds
summary: Iraq's Parliament, following months of debate, approved its 2011 budget late Sunday night after public unrest throughout the country forced politicians to divert funds for fighter jets and salaries to social programs.

headline: Morocco Joins In, Defying Predictions
summary: Five people died as a result of looting that accompanied demonstrations demanding changes to the constitution in Morocco, as the North African monarchy became the latest government subject to demands for greater democracy that are sweeping the region.

headline: Libya Unrest Pushes Up Oil Prices
summary: Crude-oil futures soared, as violent clashes between protesters and government forces in Libya revived fears that escalating demonstrations would disrupt the region's oil exports.

headline: Germany's Merck Posts 73% Gain in Net Profit
summary: Shares in Merck KGaA rose sharply as the German company forecast strong earnings and revenue growth in 2011, after reporting a 73% increase in 2010 net profit.

headline: S&P Lowers Bahrain's Rating One Notch
summary: Standard & Poor's Ratings Services cut Bahrain's sovereign rating by one notch to 'A-/A-2,' and said it expects political demonstrations there to persist.

headline: Samsonite Hires Bankers for Possible Hong Kong IPO
summary: U.S. luggage maker Samsonite has taken another step toward a possible US$1 billion listing in Hong Kong by hiring bankers, people familiar with the matter said.

headline: Tata Steel to Remain Stakeholder in Riversdale
summary: Tata Steel said it will remain as a stakeholder in Australia's Riversdale Mining as the Indian company is keen to secure coking coal supplies from Riversdale's mines in Mozambique for its global steel operations.

headline: Japan Again Upgrades Economic View
summary: The Japanese government upgraded its assessment of the economy for the second straight month in February, saying that conditions are improving as recovering exports boost production.

headline: Asia Down Slightly on Oil, Unrest
summary: Asian markets ended mostly lower Monday as escalating unrest in the Mideast and North Africa kept investors on edge, though energy-sector shares posted gains as the turmoil pushed crude-oil prices higher. Hong Kong was 0.5% lower.

headline: Euro-Zone Growth Strongest in Five Years
summary: Euro-zone private sector output is growing at the strongest rate for more than four-and-a-half years, but surging inflation suggests the European Central Bank may raise interest rates sooner than expected.

headline: Waitrose Relaunches Online Grocery Service
summary: Waitrose plans to relaunch its home delivery business with a £10 million investment, as the U.K.-based upmarket supermarket group bids to keep pace with rivals in the competitive online grocery market.

headline: Early Election Becomes a Possibility in Japan
summary: A snap election in Japan over the next few months has become a possibility in recent days as a rift widens within the ruling party and an emboldened opposition vows to block crucial budget legislation.

headline: India President: Taming Inflation is Top Priority
summary: The Indian government's top priority is to tame inflation and sustain the economy's growth momentum to help the common man, said President Pratibha Devi Singh Patil, speaking in parliament on the first day of the budget session.

headline: German Business Confidence Soars
summary: A key indicator of German business confidence rose to a new all-time high in February, despite continued signs of stress elsewhere in the euro zone and the risk of instability from the Middle East.

headline: Indian Parliament's Budget Session
summary: The budget session of India's Parliament started Monday. Some snapshots of what is in store.

headline: Opinion: China's Hooligan Government
summary: The authorities are increasingly resorting to public violence.

headline: Vietnam Takes Aim at Inflation
summary: Vietnam is expected to unveil measures aimed at curbing inflation as the government faces increasing pressure to bring greater stability to the volatile economy. The country also raised electricity prices 15.3%.

headline: Preliminary Data Show China PMI Decline
summary: HSBC's index indicated manufacturing activity growth slowed in February after it rebounded in January, which may help ease concerns about an overheating economy, though inflation pressures remain.

headline: West Australian to Buy Seven Media
summary: U.S. private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts will reduce its stake in one of Australia's leading media companies through the $4.2 billion sale of Seven Media Group to West Australian Newspapers.

headline: Asiana, KDB to Sell Korea Express Stake
summary: Korea Development Bank said it and Asiana Airlines will sell a combined 37.6% stake in logistics company Korea Express, and will aim to select a preferred bidder by May.

headline: Sehwag in Pictures
summary: India's Virender Sehwag scored 175 runs in the opening World Cup match against Bangladesh as he led his team to victory by 87 runs. Some snapshots.

headline: Injuries Hamper Cricket's World Stage
summary: The Twenty20 explosion brings cricket's overcrowded schedule to a head. Lucrative contracts have players on the field more than ever, leading to tournament-ending injuries.

headline: Thailand Emerges From Recession
summary: Thailand's economy emerged from a brief technical recession in the October-December quarter thanks to continuing healthy exports and growing private consumption, with more moderate growth forecast for 2011.

headline: Gadhafi's Son Warns of Civil War in Libya
summary: The son of Libyan leader Gadhafi warned in a nationally televised address that continued protests might lead to a civil war that could send the country's oil wells up in flames.

headline: Conflicting Agendas Doom Summits
summary: G-20 meetings are destined to end in disappointment when the leading players all have different goals.

headline: Swiss Freeze Assets Linked to Mubarak
summary: Switzerland has frozen tens of millions of Swiss francs in assets belonging to members of the former Mubarak regime in Egypt, as the U.K. and the European Union move to follow the Alpine country.

headline: Sapporo to Expand in North America
summary: Sapporo Holdings is mapping out strategies that could involve acquisitions or creating a new plant to meet rising demand for premium beer in North America. In Asia, the Japanese company is expanding its beer and soft-drink business.

headline: Zucker Moves Out of Emerging Stocks
summary: Short-term inflation worries, adverse currency movements and the necessity to reprice geopolitical risk are disrupting the long-term trend in emerging-market stocks, says Olivier Zucker, managing director of Zucker & Co Investment Advisors.

headline: Cricket World Cup Tip of the Day
summary: Fresh off a 6-1 thrashing in a seven-game One Day International series against Australia, England found some form just in time for its opening game of this competition, beating Canada and Pakistan in its final two warm-up games.

headline: Irish Banks Behind ECB Lending
summary: An unusual surge in ECB overnight lending last week was connected to Ireland's effort to wind down nationalized lenders Anglo Irish Bank and Irish Nationwide Building Society.

headline: Region's Protests Spread to Morocco
summary: Thousands of protesters took the streets in Morocco on Sunday to demand sweeping changes to the nation's constitution, defying predictions that this thousand-year-old monarchy would prove an exception to the demands for greater democracy that are sweeping the region.

headline: U.S. Navy Leader Addresses China's Rise
summary: The top U.S. naval commander for the Asian-Pacific region called on China to be "responsible and constructive" as it prepares to deploy its first aircraft carrier, while stressing that America retains substantial firepower and surveillance capabilities in the region.

headline: Ryanair to Target Ads on Boarding Passes
summary: Ryanair is teaming up with a media company to sell targeted ads aimed at passengers booking and checking in online.

headline: Groupon Gears UpTo Expand Into China
summary: Deals website Groupon appears to be making preparations to launch operations in China, a move that could shake up the market for group buying.

headline: Iceland's President Blocks Deal on Icesave
summary: Iceland's president again vetoed a bid by the Parliament to repay the U.K. and the Netherlands more than $5 billion lost by depositors in Iceland's banking collapse—sending the matter to a referendum.

headline: Merkel's Party Suffers State Defeat
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel's party suffered an electoral defeat in Hamburg, setting a tough precedent for regional votes that could weaken her authority as she steers the country through the wake of the euro-zone crisis.

headline: Swiss Banks Have to Come Clean, Says Sarasin CEO
summary: Swiss private banks have more to gain than lose from becoming less friendly to tax dodgers, argues Bank Sarasin Chief Executive Joachim Strähl.

headline: National Bank of Greece Caps Alpha Bid
summary: National Bank of Greece, the country's largest bank by assets, may be ready to slightly sweeten the bid in its friendly takeover of Alpha Bank, but isn't prepared to double the premium that Alpha is demanding, a senior person familiar with the matter said.

headline: Iran's Forces Battle Protests Nationwide
summary: For a second time in a week, Iran's opposition drew tens of thousands of supporters to the streets across the nation calling for the end to the Islamic Republic's rule.

headline: Sovereign-Debt Worries to Weigh on Euro
summary: The euro could wobble this week over sovereign-debt and banking concerns, despite Friday's gain after the hawkish comments of a European Central Bank member.

headline: China Fuel-Price Bump Complicates Inflation Fight
summary: China raised gasoline and diesel prices Sunday, a move that is meant to reflect rising international crude-oil prices but that could complicate the government's efforts to combat inflation.

headline: Mallorca Villa
summary: Tim de Rosen built his "dream home" high on the hillside of the north coast of Mallorca, in Formentor, spending â¬2.5 million and 18 months planning with local and U.K.-based architects to create the modern residence.

headline: Bahrain Is Calm; Talks to Resume
summary: Bahrain's political crisis continued to cool down as seven opposition groups working to present protesters demands said they would meet to coordinate a response to the government's call for dialogue.

headline: Call for Protests Unnerves Beijing
summary: Chinese authorities detained dozens of political activists after an anonymous online call for protests in 13 cities, though only a handful of people appear to have shown up to demonstrate.

headline: What's News
summary: Here are the top business stories from today's Wall Street Journal Asia.

headline: Diageo to Buy Turkey's Mey Içki
summary: Diageo said it will buy Turkish spirits company Mey Içki for $2.1 billion, a deal that will give the U.K. alcohol giant access to a vast distribution network in Turkey.

headline: Some Big Investors Bet on Treasury Rally
summary: Some big investors are betting that 10-year U.S. Treasury yields are likely to peak around 4% by midyear.

headline: Business Watch
summary: Here is a selection of business news from around the world from today's Wall Street Journal Europe.

headline: Hyundai Motor Cuts Its Offer
summary: South Korean conglomerate Hyundai Motor Group made a reduced offer of $4.47 billion for a controlling stake in Hyundai Engineering & Construction, an official at one of the seller companies said, bringing the drawn-out sale closer to completion.

headline: Hopu Partner Plans His Own Fund
summary: Richard Ong, one of Hopu Investment Management's founding partners, is leaving the China-focused private-equity firm to set up his own $2 billion fund, according to people familiar with the situation.

headline: World Watch
summary: Here is a selection of news from around the world from today's Wall Street Journal Europe.

headline: Gadgets Rule the 'Connected Society'
summary: Devices that point to a future in which consumers and devices are connected wirelessly were on show at Mobile World Congress in Barcelona.

headline: Why Stocks Don't Always Boom With the Economy
summary: It's an uncomfortable truth for investors: Revved-up economic growth doesn't translate into outsized gains in a country's stock prices. Look at today's emerging markets.

headline: Orphanides Urges Action on Debt Crisis
summary: Portugal could run into even deeper fiscal trouble if euro-zone governments don't accelerate steps to improve how the currency bloc is managed, said Athanasios Orphanides, one of the region's top central bankers.

headline: Weekend of Violence Leaves Scores Dead in Afghanistan
summary: A weekend of violence left scores of people dead in Afghanistan, with 38 slain in an attack on a bank branch by five suicide bombers disguised as Afghan soldiers, and dozens more reportedly killed in coalition bombardment of a remote valley.

headline: China's U.S. IPO Pipeline Quietly Grows
summary: China was the home of some of the best- and worst-performing stock offerings that hit the U.S. last year. The handful of offerings so far this year have been mediocre, but more companies from China are readying IPOs.

headline: Whose Budget Trap?
summary: A transcript of the weekend's program on FOX News Channel.
